item.title: Turkey Pursues Cleric Living in U.S., Blamed as Coup Mastermind
item.media:description: Fethullah Gulen, a Turkish cleric living in exile in the United States, denied inspiring an attempted coup in his home country.
item.media:credit: Charles Mostoller for The New York Times
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Fethullah Gulen was behind a coup attempt last week that almost succeeded in taking over the state and killing Mr. Erdogan himself.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Turkey Considers New Measures to Solidify Erdogan’s Authority
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan held a national security meeting, and purges continued in the wake of the attempt last week to topple the government.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: After Attack on German Train, Fears Over Refugees, and From Them, Too
item.media:description: The building in Ochsenfurt, southern Germany, where a refugee who attacked passengers on a train had been staying. Some migrants fear that the lone-wolf attack will inspire a new round of second-guessing about accepting immigrants.
item.media:credit: Karl-Josef Hildenbrand, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The ax and knife assault prompted worries about a fresh round of second-guessing over the effects of opening the door to so many immigrants.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: U.S. Targets $1 Billion in Assets in Malaysian Embezzlement Case
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia leaving the Time Warner Center in New York, where he has an apartment, in 2014.
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.description: The Justice Department is seeking to seize more than $1 billion in assets bought with money that it believes was stolen from 1MDB, a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: LOUISE STORY

item.title: 3 Men in India Accused of Raping Woman a Second Time
item.description: The men were among a group of five who allegedly targeted a 20-year-old college student as punishment for accusing them of raping her before.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Baishizhou Journal: Skyscrapers’ Rise in China Marks the Fall of Immigrant Enclaves
item.media:description: A market in Baishizhou in Shenzhen, China, last week. The neighborhood is in a central district of Shenzhen long valued for its potential for commercial redevelopment.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Baishizhou, an urban village within surging Shenzhen, has been a source of cheap housing for immigrants for decades, but its days are numbered.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG

item.title: Air Transat Pilots Pulled From Jet and Arrested on Suspicion of Being Drunk
item.description: The flight to Toronto from Glasgow was delayed more than 20 hours, and passengers seemed to display relief as well as outrage.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Indonesia Warns of New Enemy Lurking About: Pokémon
item.media:description: Students playing Pokémon Go at a park in Denpasar, Indonesia, on Wednesday.
item.description: Government officials are warning that the game Pokémon Go could open the door to hackers and allow the penetration of sensitive government and military sites.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Trilobites: The Otherworldly Polka Dots of Spotted Lake
item.media:description: Most of Spotted Lake’s water evaporates in the summer, leaving behind shallow pools separated from one another by salts and minerals.
item.description: As British Columbia dries out every summer, most of Spotted Lake’s water evaporates, leaving hundreds of briny pools.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Theresa May, in First Prime Minister’s Questions, Pledges Migration Cap
item.media:description: Mrs. May during her first session of Prime Minister’s Questions, at the House of Commons.
item.media:credit: Parliamentary Recording Unit, via Associated Press
item.description: Britain’s new leader took on the opposition Labour Party, before preparing to travel to Berlin to meet with Chancellor Angela Merkel.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Pavel Sheremet, Journalist in Ukraine, Is Killed in Car Bombing
item.description: Mr. Sheremet, 44, was among several well-known reporters in Russia who recently moved to Ukraine, where restrictions on the news media are looser.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Praiano Journal: By the Sea Where the Sirens Called, an Italian Town Beckons Tourists With Art
item.media:description: A view of Praiano, Italy.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Praiano, Italy, on the Amalfi Coast, has transformed itself into an open-air museum, installing local art along streets and bolstering a sense of civic pride.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: One Russian Security Agency Raids Another, in Rare Sign of Dysfunction
item.description: Three senior prosecutors were arrested as the main domestic intelligence service searched the Moscow offices of a powerful branch of the prosecutor’s office.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Labour Dissidents Unite Around Challenger to Jeremy Corbyn as Leader
item.media:description: Owen Smith during his campaign kickoff near Cardiff, Wales, on Sunday, at which he announced his candidacy to be leader of Britain’s Labour Party.
item.description: Owen Smith, the British opposition party’s former spokesman on welfare issues, won a contest for support among Labour deputies, prompting his rival to withdraw from the race.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: An Unapologetic Boris Johnson, Diplomat, Meets the Press
item.description: Britain’s new foreign secretary, known for past insults of President Obama, Hillary Clinton and others, said he would not apologize for such comments, which he said had been misconstrued.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Trilobites: Old Teeth Tell New Stories About People Who Didn’t Get Enough Sun
item.media:description: A tooth from a man buried in Quebec during the 18th or 19th century who had had rickets. Scientists recently reported that teeth contain enduring records of vitamin D deficiency.
item.description: Researchers discovered a permanent record of vitamin D deficiency in old teeth that could provide insights on rickets and children’s health today.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: In Death, Qandeel Baloch, Pakistani Social Media Star, Is Celebrated as a Feminist Hero
item.media:description: Qandeel Baloch in an undated photo.
item.description: Authorities arrested Ms. Baloch’s brother, who said he killed her because of “shameful” pictures she had posted to Facebook.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: Israeli Parliament Passes Law Enabling Ouster of Legislators
item.media:description: Hanin Zoabi, an Arab member of the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament. Legislation that would enable the suspension or ouster of members of Parliament appears to have grown out of a broad aversion to her.
item.description: The law would allow for the suspension or ouster of legislators accused of racial incitement or supporting armed struggle against Israel. Critics have called it discriminatory.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Dozens of Civilians Reported Dead in U.S.-Led Syria Airstrike
item.description: The coalition fighting ISIS in Syria and Iraq said it was investigating reports of civilian deaths near Manbij, including 56 reported by a monitoring group.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinosphere: Sorry for Having Insulted China? Here’s Your Chance to Apologize
item.media:description: The Taiwanese actor Leon Dai in 2014. Mr. Dai recently lost a leading role in a Chinese movie following online accusations that he supported Taiwan independence.
item.description: A tongue-in-cheek Facebook page invites people to apologize to the country for real or perceived slights.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: A Third of Nice Truck Attack’s Dead Were Muslim, Group Says
item.description: The Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the rampage, but it took a heavy toll on Muslims, who numbered at least 30 of the 84 killed.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and LILIA BLAISE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Philippines Clears Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, Ex-President, of Graft Charges
item.description: The Supreme Court also ordered that Mrs. Arroyo be released from a Manila hospital where she has been detained since 2012.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Liberal Chinese Journal’s Purged Editors Declare Publication Dissolved
item.media:description: Du Daozheng, who was removed last week as publisher of Yanhuang Chunqiu, in the journal’s office in Beijing in 2009.
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.description: The journal, Yanhuang Chunqiu, has carried articles advocating political change and examining delicate issues in Chinese Communist history.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Bangladesh, Blaming Local Groups for Attacks, Seeks Suspects Tied to ISIS
item.media:description: A police checkpoint along a road leading to the Holey Artisan Bakery, the site of a deadly attack this month in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
item.description: A list of suspects released after the Dhaka cafe siege includes men that the police have long sought as operatives for the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and MAHER SATTAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: KFC Targeted in Protests Over South China Sea
item.media:description: Members of a pro-Beijing political party demonstrating outside the United States Embassy in Hong Kong last week following a ruling in The Hague against Beijing’s claims in the South China Sea.
item.description: Accusing the United States of encouraging a case against China’s maritime claims, demonstrators called for boycotts in about a dozen cities.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Afghan Teenager Spoke of Friend’s Death Before Ax Attack in Germany
item.description: German investigators found evidence that may link the young man to the Islamic State, but denied a firm connection with the group despite it claiming responsibility.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: What in the World: That Green Square (or Circle) in Mexico City Might Save Your Life
item.description: Symbols painted on the sidewalks of the earthquake-prone city mark the places to gather when the tremors start.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: What in the World: Business Owners Turn to an Unlikely Mascot: Hitler
item.description: The Nazi dictator’s image has been used to sell fried chicken, shampoo and jeans in places as varied as India and the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: What in the World: Visiting Madagascar? Leave Red Swimsuits (and Lemur Recipes) at Home
item.media:description: Behavior in Madagascar is governed by thousands of cultural taboos, or fady, that may seem random and superstitious to outsiders.
item.description: Thousands of cultural taboos, or fady, are crucial to the identity and worldview of the Malagasy, but may seem random and superstitious to outsiders.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Living With Death in Baghdad
item.description: Iraqis have grown far too accustomed to a life of terrorism and corruption.
item.dc:creator: SINAN ANTOON

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: How the Internet Saved Turkey’s Internet-Hating President
item.description: Who would have guessed that free online communication would come to Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s rescue?
item.dc:creator: ZEYNEP TUFEKCI
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Theresa May’s Shock Therapy
item.media:description: Theresa May addressing the media outside 10 Downing Street on July 13.
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister wants to make things better by shaking them up.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: As Refugee Family Resettles in Sweden, 9-Year-Old Nephew Dies
item.media:description: While a nurse prepares a medicine, Nabih, 9, rests in a hospital bed next to an aunt, his brother Farid and his mother Shazia Nouri, right, at a hospital in Antalya, southern Turkey.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Ahmad Majid is one of millions of people swept up in a global refugee crisis; his resettlement in Sweden ended when his young nephew died this week.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
